awd_titl_txt: Integrative Mathematical and Experimental Approaches to Understanding Robust Activation of Gene Expression by Light Color
awd_abstract_narration:
This research defines a newly discovered light color sensing system in bacteria that has the potential to regulate responses in synthetically created bacterial life forms. Such customized organisms have the potential to produce a wide range of beneficial products for humankind, but their activities must be strictly controlled. At present, there are few highly robust control systems available to synthetic biologists, therefore the discovery and development of additional regulatory pathways is of paramount importance. Building on recent discoveries in a highly abundant, photosynthetic marine bacterium, this project uses mathematical modeling to predict the mechanism through which shifting ambient light color from green to blue results in a 35-40-fold increase in the bacterium's gene expression. The project also involves the use of molecular, genetic, and biochemical tools to test the models and define the photo-regulation process. This system has tremendous potential for significantly contributing to the areas of microbial biotechnology, green chemistry and the new and rapidly growing field of optogenetics. In addition to the basic scientific value of the project there is training received, by three graduate students, in modeling and molecular genetics research. There is also training received, in science pedagogy, by high school teachers. Students from underrepresented groups in science benefit from a summer research immersion program at Indiana University.

Mathematical modeling is used to predict the mechanism through which a newly discovered signal transduction pathway operates. Predictions from the model are tested using molecular biological and biochemical approaches. Diametrically regulated by blue and green light and widely used by Synechococcus, this simple but robust signaling system is unique. The regulation element consists of three regulatory proteins named FciA, FciB, and FciC, and three genes whose expression is highly upregulated in blue light and downregulated in green light. FciA either operates with, or independently of, FciC, and modeling these components provides weighted evidence for one of these two models. Using RNAseq and Western blot analyses a time course of RNA and protein responses is examined after a switch from growth in green light to growth in blue light. Both in vitro and in vivo approaches are used to determine the specific DNA sequences that are bound by FciA, FciB, and FciC. Methods include Electromobility Shift Assays, DNaseI footprinting, and exoChIPseq. Finally, the signaling system is transferred to another cyanobacterial species and to a non-photosynthetic bacterium to begin to develop this regulatory system for use in species that are commonly used in microbial biotechnology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The marine phytoplankton Synechococcus—the second-most abundant photosynthetic organism in the oceans—is estimated to produce 16% of the Earth's oxygen. Our studies showed that nearly 40% of Synechococcus can sense the ratio of blue light to green light and adjust their pigments to optimize light capture for photosynthesis. Such adjustments change the color of these cells, making them orange after growth in blue light and pink after growth in green light (Figure 1), and is called "Type 4 Chromatic Acclimation" (CA4).

Intellectual Merit

Our NSF grant funded the study of the regulation of CA4. We identified MpeZ and BbaA, the two proteins responsible for the pigment changes during CA4, and FciA, FciB, and FciC, the three proteins that regulate CA4. Our preliminary data suggested that FciA (activates gene expression in blue light) and FciB (represses gene expression in green light) acted before FciC. Because FciC was too small to delete with the tools available at the time, we used mathematical modeling to predict if FciC worked in concert with FciA and FciB (amplification expression model, AE) or after them (serial expression model, SE). We developed two mathematical models (using systems of four differential equations) to represent the AE and SE models, and found that both models could fit expected relative expressions equally well, but that the SE model would predict subtle differences in timing of FciC expression, with FciC abundance initially dominating MpeZ and BbaA during a light source switching. Neither model could be ruled out without further time-resolved expression data following light source switching. We also developed agent-based models (ABMs) which simulate individual cyanobacteria cells, as a theoretical platform to explore behaviors that could be up- or down-regulated by light through MpeZ. 

We developed CRISPR genetics to delete the fciC gene. We determined that CA4 operates via SE, and that FciC activates gene expression in blue light. In addition to learning how CA4 is regulated overall, we worked to characterize how FciA and FciB function. Both are AraC transcription factor family proteins, which sense and respond to many signals. Light is not one of these, so if FciA and FciB are sensing light color, they will be novel photoreceptors. AraC family members are difficult to overexpress and purify, as are FciA and FciB. However, during this grant period we succeeded in producing large amounts of highly purified FciA and FciB, which will be useful for subsequent biochemical studies.

We extended the modeling component of this work by using ABMs to explore whether these bacteria could be bioengineered to be controlled via CA4. We simulated the movement and behavior of individual cyanobacteria cells in spatial patterns of blue and green light, and added light-sensitive behavioral changes to model up- and down-regulating secretion, motility, and cycling in response to mpeZ expression. We found that modulating secretion and chemotactic responses to chemokines could be used for self-assembly into stable spatial patterns. We are now developing a final, cloud-hosted version of this model for hands-on exploration via easy “rules” (e.g., blue light increases cycling) for next-generation exploration of bioengineered cyanobacteria using CA4 for control.

Broader Impacts

This project has trained two female PhD students in Biochemistry and Intelligent Systems Engineering. The Biochemist is Native American (the Chippewa Objiwe tribe), a historically underrepresented group. One REU student supported by this grant in the Kehoe laboratory progressed to a Research Associate and has moved into private industry.

It also allowed a week's training of eight Indiana high school Biology teachers in the Kehoe laboratory over four summers in the IU Biology Summer Institute. Kehoe worked with these teachers for the entire week, planning laboratories for their classes to teach students the basics of light color regulated signal transduction. Teachers returned to their schools with turnkey-ready laboratory modules for hundreds of students for the coming year. The Kehoe laboratory also set up a booth every year for four years for hundreds of general public visitors during IU Science Fests. 

Information about this project has been disseminated to the scientific community by Kehoe, who gave four seminars at major universities around the world, one virtual talk during the pandemic and four Plenary Lectures at international meetings. Additionally, this grant funding yielded 13 scientific publications from the Kehoe laboratory and 5 from the Macklin laboratory. The Macklin laboratory adapted advances from this project to begin holding ABM workshops, training over 100 early career researchers who published dozens of articles based on our ABM tools. 

Overall, our research is providing new insights into CA4, a globally widespread and important process. There is also value in better understanding the novel CA4 regulatory system because it holds great promise for future use in the fields of optogenetics and synthetic biology.
